Vol. VI.

OCTOBER 12, 1901.

No, 1.

HOPKINS MEN AT NORTHFIELD.
ARUN has a place been more favored with natural beauty than Northfield,
the fairyland of broad green meadows and woodlands, sweet with the
singing of birds or hushed with the stillness of summer noontide ; of
mountains, forest crowned, now blue, now purple, now golden crested, now
mantled with low hanging clouds ; of a quiet out-flowing river reflecting the
Splendid flush of the sunset, the exquisite tints of twilight, or the stars of the
still night.
Here on the east bank of the Connecticut near the northern boundary of
Massachusetts, on the lower slopes of Notch Mountain stand the Cathedral
Pines Through the aisles of this dim grove we walk with reverent mind.
Stately pines all about us seem to pierce the sky. Beneath our feet the fragrant, slippery needles make us fearful of mishap. For ten remembered days
ten loyal sons of Hopkins dwelt amid this "solitude of pines with soft brown
Silences carpeted."

(1.3'

"Yet not for all this beauty would I seek
This lovely vale, but for more glorious things;
There shines the sun that shall go down no more;
There flows the fountain that shall water earth;
There bursts the glory that shall never pale ;
There springs the life with which death strives in vain;
There are the golden chains prepared and forged
Which knit our earth to heaven; there also stands
The more than golden ladder which connects
Those lower chambers with the upper halls."

Attractive as is the natural beauty of the place, the motive of the seven
hundred college men who gathered there this summer, not only in the camp but
in the less attractive dormitories of the Seminary, was rather the hope of spiritual awakening, to which the very beauty of the place itself conduces.
At this Sixteenth Annual Conference, twenty-nine different nationalities
were represented, and one hundred and forty-nine institutions of learning.
Yale as usual led in attendance (120), with Princeton second. Hopkins was
one of twelve colleges having nine or more delegates presentThe spiritual impressions were made at platform meetings, in the morning
and at night on each day by thirty-eight speakers of renown. The first few
dais were especially marked by the addresses of Mr. Morgan, as were the clos-

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ing days by those of Mr. Robert Speer. To conserve and deepen these impressions, Bible classes, a Missionary Institute, and other departments were led by
competent men, among whom were Profs Bosworth and King of Oberlin, and
Sanders of Yale. As there were present twenty-eight foreign delegates, the
missionary interest was very strong, and Hopkins should rejoice to know that
two of her ten men volunteered for the foreign field while there.
Awakened amid the twitter of the early birds by the pulling of your cot
from beneath your weary bones, you bathe your sleepy eyes in mountain dew
stolen from your neighbor's pail, and are hardly through with your lavations
before the clang of a high-sounding cymbal calls you to the morning "hashhouse" meal (if it be not some mischievous chap abusing his wash-basin.)
About you at the table are many men of many minds from many colleges, in
many stages of attire, calling lustily for the "pump" or the "cow'S—as their
taste or rather thirst may dictate.
A missionary institute at eight, or a Bible class at nine, calls you across
fields
tenanted with bleating sheep to the group of Seminary buildings not
the
far away. At ten in the large Auditorium you hear such addresses by the very
foremost religious thinkers as are seldom offered elsewhere. Back to camp for
dinner, you have the afternoon for personal talks with the leading men of the
conference, or for sport. If the latter, perhaps today it is a plunge into the
cool waters of the nearby Connecticut just as Nature made you, tomorrow a
tramp through the three adjoining states of Vermont, New Hampshire and
Massachusetts, or perhaps a long drive, with the rest of your delegation, amid
the beautiful hills with which the region abounds, and from which vistas of
natural beauty present pictures that still linger in your mind. Yet within
the Seminary grounds are found abundant opportunities for athletic endeavor.
Regular match games of base-ball are scheduled between teams of the attending colleges, a tennis tournament, with singles and doubles, a golf tournament,
and on ,the Fourth of July a special field day. This year Yale won the chain
pionship in these events; R. H. Schauffler of Princeton defeated Ludington of
Yale in a closely contested tennis tournament. These two colleges also played
the finals for the baseball championship, Yale winning by a score of ten to
seven. As yet Hopkins has had no part in these games, but as she is gradually
coming into more prominence in other lines, it, behooves the athletic element
among us to look out for Hopkins' honors in that direction also.
At sunset the Conference gathers on 'Round Top" where rests the body
of Mr. Moody, and "Life-work Talks" are given by men prominent in the different professions. These are perhaps the most stirring addresses in the ten
days' program. From "Round Top" across the hills to the Auditorium for
the platform meeting of the evening, you go amid the glories of a Northfield
sunset. There below is the calm, green valley, beautiful in its stillness, with
its meadows, its clustering houses and trees, the shining river curving through
the midst, and beyond, the best of all, the everlasting hills with their constantly
changing lights and shadows. Presently twilight falls and soon a hundred
lights from "Hermon's wooded hill" flash out, and nearby the Seminary lights
are also gleaming.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

At 9.30 you wend your way to the camp guided by the moon's soft rays,
and there, in the quiet second thought following the evening's address, are held
Delegation Meetings," in which the fellows come to know each other as never
before. Then to peaceful slumbers amid the stately pines—provided no "rough
house" is on foot to disturb the wee hours of the morn.
Fourth of July night is a gala occasion never forgotten by those participating. The large Auditorium is profusely decorated with college and state colors,
a certain pro rata space being assigned te each college. Lockstep marching to
college tunes prevails all over the house for half an hour, and then after an ad•
dress by Pres. Seth Low on "The Responsibilities of the College Man to the
State," each delegation has an opportunity to give its yell, sing a song, if large
enough, do any "stunt" of special attraction that can be devised. In this Hopkins is in the van; "the hit" of the evening being that arranged for the "Medical Schools of Baltimore." A skeleton specially devised and sheeted with skull,
arm, and foot distinctly visible, previously concealed behind the platform suddenly rushes out over the heads of the astonished multitude during the singing
of our song, along the supporting ropes reaching to the vaulted roof float the
banners of the different medical schools of Baltimore.
The responses of the foreign delegates form a chief feature of the evening,
especially those of the dozen Japanese students, whose singing(?) rivals that of
the Hopkins Glee Club. The jolly times with these foreign delegates when they
visited the camp will be long remembered. Pastor Hoffman, of Geneva, who
Styled himself "The Veldt's Committee," a chief justice of Hungary, a native
lawyer from Labore, and many others of exceedingly attractive personality
mingled with delightful and helpful freedom among the fellows at our camp.
One event worth special mention was the large reception given the entire
conference by the Yale delegation in East Hall. Another was the "night shirt
brigade" which arose, like the mushroon, to full strength in a single night.
Started by only a handful at the top of the hill in the dead of night, not twenty
minutes passed before every man in camp had either arisen in response to the
call "everybody out" or had suffered his cot to depart from under him, and his
bedclothes to be scattered to the wind.
A hundred and twenty fellows in pajamas sitting on the top rail of a worm
fence at one thirty a. m., singing "Good Night Ladies" was certainly worthy
of a flashlight and further investigation.
Time and space would fail to tell of what we did; all that ten loyal Hopkinsians could devise was done. Is not that enough?
Those in the delegation, which was the same size as last year, were Dr. P.
S. Evans, Jr., Med., C. K. Edmunds,'97, A. W. Freeman, G. S., R. L. McAll,
'00, A. R. Bird,'01, G. E.. Snavely, '01, H. W. Plaggemeyer,'03, R. C. Pagon,
C. K. E.
'03, J. H. Addison, '03, R. S. Licking, '04.

HE NEWS LETTER greets its readers in new form. We have deemed it ad-

t

visable to adopt the present shape for several reasons, the most important
of which is that we believe our readers will find the present magazine
form more desirable and less inconvenient to handle than the old design. In
the course of the ensuing year the NEWS-LETTER desires to come into close
touch with every student of the University, and in order to accomplish this
every effort will be made to publish such news as will interest all Hopkins
students. With this end in view we propose to extend our field to the Medical
School, to devote a portion of each issue to Medical School items, and to supplement our present staff of editors by the addition of a Medical School Editor.
With the exception of the "Hullabaloo," the NEWS-LETTER is the only
student publication at Hopkins, and for this reason we wish every student to
take a personal interest in the paper. It is yours, support it, encourage it, improve it by helpful criticism given in proper spirit, and in return it will endeavor
to give you a representative college journal.
URING the past five months misfortune has dealt us several cruel blows.
Never before in the history of the University has death claimed so many
of our Faculty in so brief a period of time. Just before the university
closed last spring, the whole scientific world was called upon to mourn with us
the loss of one its greatest thinkers and inventors—Professor Rowland.
As we commence our 26th academic year we find three distinguished names
missing from our Faculty roll—Dr. Herbert B. Adams, Professor Emeritus of
American an? Institutional History; Dr. Sidney Sherwood, Associate Professor

g

THE NEWS—LETTER. -

5

in Political Economy, and Dr. Morris C. Sutphen, Instructor in Latin. The
loss to an institution, of four such men cannot be estimated, it can, however,
be felt—felt most deeply.

t

HE halls of old Johns Hopkins are open for another academic year, and
another class, untutored and untrained along the lines of University
thought and action has entered.
To the'class, known in the college world as Freshinan, the NEWS-LETTIM
extends its greeting and a bit of advice. Remember, first of all, that you are
now an integral part of a great University, and the position carries with it a
certain amount of responsibility; your alma mater is beginning a great work for
YOU; in return you owe her something, nor is this duty entirely absolved by
faithful and constant effort in class work, for apart from the high standard of
scholarship necessary in order to be a Hopkins student, there are certain other
responsibilities devolving upon you. The first of these is unswerving loyalty
to the Black and Blue, a loyalty stronger and deeper than a mere preparatory
school affiliation, a loyalty which, despite storm and tempest, will never be
Shaken, Perhaps you have some latent talent, beside your natural inclination (?)
to study. If such be the case now is the time to bring it forth. The students
maintain athletic teams, musical clubs, and two publications. If athletically
inclined try for a place on the foot ball, lacrosse, or track and field team; if
music proves the greater charm there are Glee, Banjo and Mandolin Clubs; if
You have a bent for the literary side there is the NEWS-LETTER. Last of all,
but by no means least, there is your support which all three of the above named
departments of undergraduate effort need and solicit. Other classes have lived
Up to expectations, shown college spirit, supported college institutions—now
lireshmen "go and do likewise."

G

ACH year we notice the increasing tendency among American colleges to
emulate the example of the Johns Hopkins University in two important
respects, the first of which is to reduce from four to three years the course
of study leading to the degree of Bachelor of Arts, and second to require an A.
B. from students wishing to take up the study of medicine. Within the past
two years the University of Pennsylvania has adopted the latter course, and
several other medical universities now announce the same policy. Beyond
question this is excellent policy. A man taking up medicine as a profession
Should have something more than a mere elementary knowledge of the first
Principles of education. Yet many medical schools admit men who have not
Completed their public school course. As a consequence the finished products
turned out" by the institutions of medicine are not of a finished nature. On
the other hand it is advisable to reduce the length of the under-graduate course
and place an A. B. within reach of a man after a period of three instead of four
Years work. The extra year thus gained means a great deal to many a young
man who enters the field of medicine, law, or any kindred science requiring a
Special course. At the same time he may feel that he is in no sense a loser, for

6

THE NEWS—LETTER.

the three year curriculum of to-day embraces as much as the four year curriculum of twenty or thirty years ago. More attention is paid to the practical side
of knowledge, and effort is made to school the college man of to-day in those
studies which will be of the greatest use to him in after life. Even to the man
who contemplates entering business at the expiration of his undergraduate
course, the three year curriculum will be of advantage, for as the term of college
life is shortened every effort will be made to conform the course to the
student's needs,concentrating his energies upon the most useful subjects for his
branch of work, and eliminating those which will be of little advantage to him.
Finally, in an age of hurry, of stimulated energy, and gigantic enterprise, an
age in which every hour is of importance and value to a man entering a business career, a young man is given the advantage of another year, and thus
enabled to begin the struggle for existence one year sooner.
HE Hopkins foot ball season has opened under the most auspicious
circumstances. It is true our team has been somewhat crippled by the
loss of several of last year's best players. Still, judging from the
amount of interest and enthusiasm manifested by the students, and particularly
the students of the Medical School, it is probable that this year's team will be
one of the best Hopkins has ever put upon the field. The securing of a firstclass coach is an innovation, the advantages of which cannot be too strongly
emphasized. In securing Mr. Dickson of University of Pennsylvania, the
University has taken a step in the right direction, the significance of which will
be better appreciated when the foot ball season is more advanced. Through
the generosity of the musical clubs in so kindly donating one hundred dollars,
the foot ball team will start a training table.
In order that the entire student body may have an opportunity to witness
the games this fall, the management has decided to issue season tickets, admitting to five games, for one dollar and a half, thus selling admissions to five
games for the price of three.

Z

FACULTY VACATIONS.
R. REMSEN spent a very profitable and refreshing summer in New England. He began with a walking trip through the Berkshire Hills, Massachusetts, as was his habit when a professor at Williams College.
Afterwards he was at Springfield, Massachusetts, and Northeast Harbor, Maine,
being at the latter place a next door neighbor of Dr. Gilman. Besides this outdoor activity, Dr. Remsen employed his leisure in preparing for the printer
another of his series of chemistry text-books.
Dr. Osier, Hopkins professor of medicine, traveled during the summer
months in England and on the Continent, taking time to attend the London
Tuberculosis Congress. Dr. Osler says great physicians no longer think much
of drugs in the treatment of this disease. It is now regarded as contagious,
and the best treatment is considered to consist in the proper inspection, sanitation, and other hygienic measures.

OUTLOOK FOR COMING SEASON.
T IS always the case at the opening of the scholastic year at the Hopkins
that the Athletic outlook is of anything but brightest hue, and the year
just started has but little more prospect than former ones. In all branches
men have been lost,—some by graduation, some by "quituation," and still
others have been compelled to forego all sports for the sake of their University
work.
In football, in track and field work, and in lacrosse heavy losses have been
sustained. The foot ball team has lost such men as Hancock, Butler, Morse,
Schmitters, Meadows, Bruton, Riggs, and others who aided us to victory last
Year. To he sure, their places in part have been filled by the acquisition of new
men from the freshmen ranks and the further developement of such stand-bys as
Blanck, Straus, Yearley and Sayler; but the whipping into shape of the new
men gives the team a hard handicap to overcome.
The track team has lost Whitman, the man who could sprint, and who
could equally well put the shot. Riggs refuses to enter athletics again, saying
that his work at the medical school has become of such a nature that he can not
afford to slight it "at this stage of the game." Others, too, have gone whose
aid in winning victories for the Black and Blue will be sorely missed. But
many of the old men have returned who will furnish the bone and sinew for the
team, and, no doubt, will get together a team worthy of the University.
The lacrosse squad has been diminished by the graduation of Bruton,
Bandel, and Tyler from the collegiate department, and of Maddren from the
Medical School. Maddren's loss will be most keenly felt, for aside from playing the game in a masterly fashion, he knew all its fine points, and has for a
couple of years acted as head coach for our team. Abercrombie, Briscoe, and
B. M. Bernheim are at the Medical School, and the remainder of the team is
still in the undergraduate department. The loss in number does not appear
especially great, but when the ability of the men is taken into consideration the
heavy loss can be appreciated.
The incoming class seems very enthusiastic over all sorts of sports, so we
do not think that there can he much doubt as to the superiority of our teams for

5

4

12

THE NEWS—LETTER.

the coming year. But let us impress upon all the necessity of all turning out.
"No," we hear you say, "what's the use of my trying to do anything. I am
worthless, so why should I go to the trouble of 'turning out.'" No, my friend,
you are not "worthless." Come out and show your spirit, and do your best,
something will happen. Some of the best athletes ever produced at this Uni versity were men like you. They had to be coaxed to come out. They thought
themselves "good for nothing," but when they got under the care of a trainer,
they developed, and showed such magnificent qualities that they really surprised
themselves
So, young man, come out, and do your level best for her whom we all love—
our Alma Mater.
PROSPECT FOR FOOT BALL.
UST at present Foot Ball is the engrossing topic. This year Hopkins has
two entirely new features to boast of, viz.: a coach and a training table.
Mr. Dickson, of the U. of P., will handle the men during the season, and
expresses the opinion that a winning team will do the honors for Old Tom
Hopkins on the gridiron. The team will, no doubt, be lighter than last year's,
averaging not over 150 lbs., but this feature will be supplemented by speed and
concerted team work. There's lots of new material this year and some of it
appears to be very good, but we can make no prophecies just yet, as the task
of weeding out the team has not begun. All the candidates are, however, to
be congratulated on their enthusiasm and interest as shown by the large
,numbers which are present for daily practice. There is a rumor afloat that
several Meds, besides those who have already shown up will join these swelling
ranks of Black and Blue Warriors, and there is some splendid material in the
Medical School. The first game is with Rock Hill, at the American League
Park, Saturday, and we prophesy that Rock Hill will count her score with
one oval figure. Season tickets will be sold this year at $1.50 for the entire
schedule of games to be played by J. H. U. in Baltimore, including all the
championship games, also the game with U. of Md. We add in conclusion:
Everybody out next Saturday, the rooting promises to be something fierce; woe
unto the freshman whose chubby face is not to be seen there.

3

THE GALLERY.
MPROVEMENT is the mark of the age. Last year THE NEWS LETTER
several times called attention to changes being made in and around the
Gymnasium building, and this year, for the first time is it noticed that
accommodations for visitors and onlookers in the cage are both sufficient and
convenient. The gallery was spoken of two years ago and finally built during
the last few weeks of last season. So far the gallery leads in the list of
improvements to our athletic accommodations which began with the building
of the cage some few years ago and have continued ever since. Some day we
will have a swimming pool, Thanks, Mack!

3

THE NEWS-LETTER.

.

13

Now that the gallery is ready for occupancy by interested spectators of
team practice, would it be out of place to remind students and others that one
of the main purposes in building it was to save the running track? Formerly
the track was at the mercy of all onlookers in the cage, and it required Mack's
best efforts to keep it in any sort of condition for his men to train. Now we
Should all remember that the cage is for players, the track for runners and the
gallery for spectators.
OUR PHILIPPINE DEPARTMENT.
OHNS Hopkins is the first institution in the country to start a course of
instruction in the dialects, manners and customs of our Eastern possessions. For some time past, the University ha been collecting the available
literature concerning the habits and language of the Filipinos, and now the library contains practically all the books of any value on these subjects to be had
in this country. Dr. Haupt, head of the department of Semitic languages, will
have immediate supervision of the work. The first course offered is an elective
in Tagalog, given by Mr. F. R. Blake, formerly a fellow of the University. Mr.
Blake has specialized in Sanskrit and in the Semitic languages. As the Malay
dialects are mixtures of Sanskrit and Arabic, he is especially well qualified for
the work. Since all the valuable works on this subject are in Spanish or German, Mr. Blake is preparing an English manual of the dialects used on the
islands, designed both for students and for general use.
It is hard to overestimate the importance of this department, and the honor
accruing to the Hopkins for its enterprise in founding it. In Dr. Haupt's words,
concerning the great Sepoy rebellion, "if the English authorities had consulted
anybody familiar with the prejudices of the natives, they would never have
compelled the use of those bullets greased with the fat that was an abomination
to Hindoo and Mohommedan alike. The U. S. Bureau of Ethnology has
already saved to the Government millions of dollars in its dealings with the
Indians." From this is seen the necessity to our country, soon to be a power
in the Orient, of such courses and instructions.
Dr. Haupt has also in view an encyclopedia of the industries, the economical, political, and religious life of the Philippines. For this work, also to be
Published under the auspices of the Hopkins, there has already been enlisted
the assistance of Dr. A. B. Meyer, of Dresden, and Dr. Blumentritt, of Seilmeritz.

wear Sister Maggie's dress skirts as kilts and carry along the baby's feeding

14

THE NEWS—LETTER.

but don't run away. The Juniors love you, and will make you feel queer. So
be happy.
LESSON IV.
Whose child is this? It looks around as if it were lost. It really seems to
have lost the lower portion of its pantaloons. Hit it with an Indian club and
see if it will holler. It is calling for the nurse girl. Shove it into long
trousers, place it tenderly in a basket, and send the remains home to dear Papa.

"IN MEMORIAM."
Oh, why will the fortune of life play such pranks?
And why will it out down the young and the brave?
The arch-fiend has busied himself in our ranks,
And carried one off like a dastardly knave.
Had he come, as of yore, with armor and shield,
A warrior tried, seasoned, bearded and gray,
We had fought him and conquered, and forced him to yield
For to win every battle is naughty-two's way.
But he came as an infant all naked and bare,
Deserted, alone, in the mystery of night.
We clothed him and fondled him, gave him our care,
Then why should ho harm us? Oh, say was it right?
Full of treachery and guile with intent to deceive,
He fixed upon one of us innocent youths,
Whispered tales in his ear, that made Law believe,
And made terrible lies, seem like beautiful truths.
Oh, he carried Law off to the false land of dreams,
Deceived by a kiss so subtle and sly,
And now in my sleep I hear pitiful screams;
Our poor comrade tortured, and none of us by.
Oh, Law, fare thee well, thou art gone from us now.
Forever and aye to thy destiny tied,
We will grieve, and in prayer our knee lightly bow;
And mourn for a comrade who lately has died.
—F. L. G-. '02.

NEW UNIVERSITY SONGS.

4T
4j HAS seemed strange to many people outside of the University that the
Hopkins has so few college songs. Some persons have even hinted that
the reason for this was a lack of true college spirit. This explanation,
however, is most decidedly erroneous, for to those who have looked into the
matter at all it is evident that the true reason could more surely be found in
the fact that never before has the attention of the student body been drawn to
the subject of college songs.
"To this end the musical organizations have determined to open a prize
competition for the best words, set either to original or popular music. Of
course, if a song with original words and music is handed in, it will be given

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

preference to verses alone—yet if the words are set to some air which can be
used in the Glee Club or on the athletic grounds, provided neither "Dixie" nor
Georgia" is used, it will stand nearly as good a chance of taking a prize as
the song with original music.
"Three prizes have been offered—the first of $10.00, the second of $5.00,
and the third of $3.00. The Judges will be Dr. Herbert E. Green and Messrs.
E. L. Turnbull, J A. E. Eyster, E. Smith and H. Eager. The prizes will be
decided by the vote of these men.
"It is hoped that every man at present in the University and those formerly
connected with it will take part in this contest, either from a desire to win a
Prize, or from his love for his Alma Mater, or—better yet—from a happy combination of both these incentives."
The above announcement was published in the May issue of the NEWSLETTER, and the competition was to have closed in June. But, after some
consideration, it was decided by those who had charge of the matter to postpone the final decision till the first of November.
By this change more men were given an opportunity to compete; and there
was a greater chance of composing and writing some really good songs.
If a sufficient number of songs are handed in, the committee will have
them published in book form, and thus give to the University the first book of
entirely original Hopkins songs.
Surely, with such a result to crown his efforts, every student who can make
the slightest attempt at poetry should enter the competition, for not only will
he be aiding his college, but he may incidentally win an enviable reputation
and a little cheering' reward.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

OCTOBER 12, 1901.

•

No, 1.

HOPKINS MEN AT NORTHFIELD.
ARUN has a place been more favored with natural beauty than Northfield,
the fairyland of broad green meadows and woodlands, sweet with the
singing of birds or hushed with the stillness of summer noontide ; of
mountains, forest crowned, now blue, now purple, now golden crested, now
mantled with low hanging clouds ; of a quiet out-flowing river reflecting the
Splendid flush of the sunset, the exquisite tints of twilight, or the stars of the
still night.
Here on the east bank of the Connecticut near the northern boundary of
Massachusetts, on the lower slopes of Notch Mountain stand the Cathedral
Pines Through the aisles of this dim grove we walk with reverent mind.
Stately pines all about us seem to pierce the sky. Beneath our feet the fragrant, slippery needles make us fearful of mishap. For ten remembered days
ten loyal sons of Hopkins dwelt amid this "solitude of pines with soft brown
Silences carpeted."

(1.3'

"Yet not for all this beauty would I seek
This lovely vale, but for more glorious things;
There shines the sun that shall go down no more;
There flows the fountain that shall water earth;
There bursts the glory that shall never pale ;
There springs the life with which death strives in vain;
There are the golden chains prepared and forged
Which knit our earth to heaven; there also stands
The more than golden ladder which connects
Those lower chambers with the upper halls."

Attractive as is the natural beauty of the place, the motive of the seven
hundred college men who gathered there this summer, not only in the camp but
in the less attractive dormitories of the Seminary, was rather the hope of spiritual awakening, to which the very beauty of the place itself conduces.
At this Sixteenth Annual Conference, twenty-nine different nationalities
were represented, and one hundred and forty-nine institutions of learning.
Yale as usual led in attendance (120), with Princeton second. Hopkins was
one of twelve colleges having nine or more delegates presentThe spiritual impressions were made at platform meetings, in the morning
and at night on each day by thirty-eight speakers of renown. The first few
dais were especially marked by the addresses of Mr. Morgan, as were the clos-

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ing days by those of Mr. Robert Speer. To conserve and deepen these impressions, Bible classes, a Missionary Institute, and other departments were led by
competent men, among whom were Profs Bosworth and King of Oberlin, and
Sanders of Yale. As there were present twenty-eight foreign delegates, the
missionary interest was very strong, and Hopkins should rejoice to know that
two of her ten men volunteered for the foreign field while there.
Awakened amid the twitter of the early birds by the pulling of your cot
from beneath your weary bones, you bathe your sleepy eyes in mountain dew
stolen from your neighbor's pail, and are hardly through with your lavations
before the clang of a high-sounding cymbal calls you to the morning "hashhouse" meal (if it be not some mischievous chap abusing his wash-basin.)
About you at the table are many men of many minds from many colleges, in
many stages of attire, calling lustily for the "pump" or the "cow'S—as their
taste or rather thirst may dictate.
A missionary institute at eight, or a Bible class at nine, calls you across
fields
tenanted with bleating sheep to the group of Seminary buildings not
the
far away. At ten in the large Auditorium you hear such addresses by the very
foremost religious thinkers as are seldom offered elsewhere. Back to camp for
dinner, you have the afternoon for personal talks with the leading men of the
conference, or for sport. If the latter, perhaps today it is a plunge into the
cool waters of the nearby Connecticut just as Nature made you, tomorrow a
tramp through the three adjoining states of Vermont, New Hampshire and
Massachusetts, or perhaps a long drive, with the rest of your delegation, amid
the beautiful hills with which the region abounds, and from which vistas of
natural beauty present pictures that still linger in your mind. Yet within
the Seminary grounds are found abundant opportunities for athletic endeavor.
Regular match games of base-ball are scheduled between teams of the attending colleges, a tennis tournament, with singles and doubles, a golf tournament,
and on ,the Fourth of July a special field day. This year Yale won the chain
pionship in these events; R. H. Schauffler of Princeton defeated Ludington of
Yale in a closely contested tennis tournament. These two colleges also played
the finals for the baseball championship, Yale winning by a score of ten to
seven. As yet Hopkins has had no part in these games, but as she is gradually
coming into more prominence in other lines, it, behooves the athletic element
among us to look out for Hopkins' honors in that direction also.
At sunset the Conference gathers on 'Round Top" where rests the body
of Mr. Moody, and "Life-work Talks" are given by men prominent in the different professions. These are perhaps the most stirring addresses in the ten
days' program. From "Round Top" across the hills to the Auditorium for
the platform meeting of the evening, you go amid the glories of a Northfield
sunset. There below is the calm, green valley, beautiful in its stillness, with
its meadows, its clustering houses and trees, the shining river curving through
the midst, and beyond, the best of all, the everlasting hills with their constantly
changing lights and shadows. Presently twilight falls and soon a hundred
lights from "Hermon's wooded hill" flash out, and nearby the Seminary lights
are also gleaming.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

At 9.30 you wend your way to the camp guided by the moon's soft rays,
and there, in the quiet second thought following the evening's address, are held
Delegation Meetings," in which the fellows come to know each other as never
before. Then to peaceful slumbers amid the stately pines—provided no "rough
house" is on foot to disturb the wee hours of the morn.
Fourth of July night is a gala occasion never forgotten by those participating. The large Auditorium is profusely decorated with college and state colors,
a certain pro rata space being assigned te each college. Lockstep marching to
college tunes prevails all over the house for half an hour, and then after an ad•
dress by Pres. Seth Low on "The Responsibilities of the College Man to the
State," each delegation has an opportunity to give its yell, sing a song, if large
enough, do any "stunt" of special attraction that can be devised. In this Hopkins is in the van; "the hit" of the evening being that arranged for the "Medical Schools of Baltimore." A skeleton specially devised and sheeted with skull,
arm, and foot distinctly visible, previously concealed behind the platform suddenly rushes out over the heads of the astonished multitude during the singing
of our song, along the supporting ropes reaching to the vaulted roof float the
banners of the different medical schools of Baltimore.
The responses of the foreign delegates form a chief feature of the evening,
especially those of the dozen Japanese students, whose singing(?) rivals that of
the Hopkins Glee Club. The jolly times with these foreign delegates when they
visited the camp will be long remembered. Pastor Hoffman, of Geneva, who
Styled himself "The Veldt's Committee," a chief justice of Hungary, a native
lawyer from Labore, and many others of exceedingly attractive personality
mingled with delightful and helpful freedom among the fellows at our camp.
One event worth special mention was the large reception given the entire
conference by the Yale delegation in East Hall. Another was the "night shirt
brigade" which arose, like the mushroon, to full strength in a single night.
Started by only a handful at the top of the hill in the dead of night, not twenty
minutes passed before every man in camp had either arisen in response to the
call "everybody out" or had suffered his cot to depart from under him, and his
bedclothes to be scattered to the wind.
A hundred and twenty fellows in pajamas sitting on the top rail of a worm
fence at one thirty a. m., singing "Good Night Ladies" was certainly worthy
of a flashlight and further investigation.
Time and space would fail to tell of what we did; all that ten loyal Hopkinsians could devise was done. Is not that enough?
Those in the delegation, which was the same size as last year, were Dr. P.
S. Evans, Jr., Med., C. K. Edmunds,'97, A. W. Freeman, G. S., R. L. McAll,
'00, A. R. Bird,'01, G. E.. Snavely, '01, H. W. Plaggemeyer,'03, R. C. Pagon,
C. K. E.
'03, J. H. Addison, '03, R. S. Licking, '04.

HE NEWS LETTER greets its readers in new form. We have deemed it ad-

t

visable to adopt the present shape for several reasons, the most important
of which is that we believe our readers will find the present magazine
form more desirable and less inconvenient to handle than the old design. In
the course of the ensuing year the NEWS-LETTER desires to come into close
touch with every student of the University, and in order to accomplish this
every effort will be made to publish such news as will interest all Hopkins
students. With this end in view we propose to extend our field to the Medical
School, to devote a portion of each issue to Medical School items, and to supplement our present staff of editors by the addition of a Medical School Editor.
With the exception of the "Hullabaloo," the NEWS-LETTER is the only
student publication at Hopkins, and for this reason we wish every student to
take a personal interest in the paper. It is yours, support it, encourage it, improve it by helpful criticism given in proper spirit, and in return it will endeavor
to give you a representative college journal.
URING the past five months misfortune has dealt us several cruel blows.
Never before in the history of the University has death claimed so many
of our Faculty in so brief a period of time. Just before the university
closed last spring, the whole scientific world was called upon to mourn with us
the loss of one its greatest thinkers and inventors—Professor Rowland.
As we commence our 26th academic year we find three distinguished names
missing from our Faculty roll—Dr. Herbert B. Adams, Professor Emeritus of
American an? Institutional History; Dr. Sidney Sherwood, Associate Professor

g

THE NEWS—LETTER. -

5

in Political Economy, and Dr. Morris C. Sutphen, Instructor in Latin. The
loss to an institution, of four such men cannot be estimated, it can, however,
be felt—felt most deeply.

t

HE halls of old Johns Hopkins are open for another academic year, and
another class, untutored and untrained along the lines of University
thought and action has entered.
To the'class, known in the college world as Freshinan, the NEWS-LETTIM
extends its greeting and a bit of advice. Remember, first of all, that you are
now an integral part of a great University, and the position carries with it a
certain amount of responsibility; your alma mater is beginning a great work for
YOU; in return you owe her something, nor is this duty entirely absolved by
faithful and constant effort in class work, for apart from the high standard of
scholarship necessary in order to be a Hopkins student, there are certain other
responsibilities devolving upon you. The first of these is unswerving loyalty
to the Black and Blue, a loyalty stronger and deeper than a mere preparatory
school affiliation, a loyalty which, despite storm and tempest, will never be
Shaken, Perhaps you have some latent talent, beside your natural inclination (?)
to study. If such be the case now is the time to bring it forth. The students
maintain athletic teams, musical clubs, and two publications. If athletically
inclined try for a place on the foot ball, lacrosse, or track and field team; if
music proves the greater charm there are Glee, Banjo and Mandolin Clubs; if
You have a bent for the literary side there is the NEWS-LETTER. Last of all,
but by no means least, there is your support which all three of the above named
departments of undergraduate effort need and solicit. Other classes have lived
Up to expectations, shown college spirit, supported college institutions—now
lireshmen "go and do likewise."

G

ACH year we notice the increasing tendency among American colleges to
emulate the example of the Johns Hopkins University in two important
respects, the first of which is to reduce from four to three years the course
of study leading to the degree of Bachelor of Arts, and second to require an A.
B. from students wishing to take up the study of medicine. Within the past
two years the University of Pennsylvania has adopted the latter course, and
several other medical universities now announce the same policy. Beyond
question this is excellent policy. A man taking up medicine as a profession
Should have something more than a mere elementary knowledge of the first
Principles of education. Yet many medical schools admit men who have not
Completed their public school course. As a consequence the finished products
turned out" by the institutions of medicine are not of a finished nature. On
the other hand it is advisable to reduce the length of the under-graduate course
and place an A. B. within reach of a man after a period of three instead of four
Years work. The extra year thus gained means a great deal to many a young
man who enters the field of medicine, law, or any kindred science requiring a
Special course. At the same time he may feel that he is in no sense a loser, for

6

THE NEWS—LETTER.

the three year curriculum of to-day embraces as much as the four year curriculum of twenty or thirty years ago. More attention is paid to the practical side
of knowledge, and effort is made to school the college man of to-day in those
studies which will be of the greatest use to him in after life. Even to the man
who contemplates entering business at the expiration of his undergraduate
course, the three year curriculum will be of advantage, for as the term of college
life is shortened every effort will be made to conform the course to the
student's needs,concentrating his energies upon the most useful subjects for his
branch of work, and eliminating those which will be of little advantage to him.
Finally, in an age of hurry, of stimulated energy, and gigantic enterprise, an
age in which every hour is of importance and value to a man entering a business career, a young man is given the advantage of another year, and thus
enabled to begin the struggle for existence one year sooner.
HE Hopkins foot ball season has opened under the most auspicious
circumstances. It is true our team has been somewhat crippled by the
loss of several of last year's best players. Still, judging from the
amount of interest and enthusiasm manifested by the students, and particularly
the students of the Medical School, it is probable that this year's team will be
one of the best Hopkins has ever put upon the field. The securing of a firstclass coach is an innovation, the advantages of which cannot be too strongly
emphasized. In securing Mr. Dickson of University of Pennsylvania, the
University has taken a step in the right direction, the significance of which will
be better appreciated when the foot ball season is more advanced. Through
the generosity of the musical clubs in so kindly donating one hundred dollars,
the foot ball team will start a training table.
In order that the entire student body may have an opportunity to witness
the games this fall, the management has decided to issue season tickets, admitting to five games, for one dollar and a half, thus selling admissions to five
games for the price of three.

FACULTY VACATIONS.
R. REMSEN spent a very profitable and refreshing summer in New England. He began with a walking trip through the Berkshire Hills, Massachusetts, as was his habit when a professor at Williams College.
Afterwards he was at Springfield, Massachusetts, and Northeast Harbor, Maine,
being at the latter place a next door neighbor of Dr. Gilman. Besides this outdoor activity, Dr. Remsen employed his leisure in preparing for the printer
another of his series of chemistry text-books.
Dr. Osier, Hopkins professor of medicine, traveled during the summer
months in England and on the Continent, taking time to attend the London
Tuberculosis Congress. Dr. Osler says great physicians no longer think much
of drugs in the treatment of this disease. It is now regarded as contagious,
and the best treatment is considered to consist in the proper inspection, sanitation, and other hygienic measures.

OUTLOOK FOR COMING SEASON.
T IS always the case at the opening of the scholastic year at the Hopkins
that the Athletic outlook is of anything but brightest hue, and the year
just started has but little more prospect than former ones. In all branches
men have been lost,—some by graduation, some by "quituation," and still
others have been compelled to forego all sports for the sake of their University
work.
In football, in track and field work, and in lacrosse heavy losses have been
sustained. The foot ball team has lost such men as Hancock, Butler, Morse,
Schmitters, Meadows, Bruton, Riggs, and others who aided us to victory last
Year. To he sure, their places in part have been filled by the acquisition of new
men from the freshmen ranks and the further developement of such stand-bys as
Blanck, Straus, Yearley and Sayler; but the whipping into shape of the new
men gives the team a hard handicap to overcome.
The track team has lost Whitman, the man who could sprint, and who
could equally well put the shot. Riggs refuses to enter athletics again, saying
that his work at the medical school has become of such a nature that he can not
afford to slight it "at this stage of the game." Others, too, have gone whose
aid in winning victories for the Black and Blue will be sorely missed. But
many of the old men have returned who will furnish the bone and sinew for the
team, and, no doubt, will get together a team worthy of the University.
The lacrosse squad has been diminished by the graduation of Bruton,
Bandel, and Tyler from the collegiate department, and of Maddren from the
Medical School. Maddren's loss will be most keenly felt, for aside from playing the game in a masterly fashion, he knew all its fine points, and has for a
couple of years acted as head coach for our team. Abercrombie, Briscoe, and
B. M. Bernheim are at the Medical School, and the remainder of the team is
still in the undergraduate department. The loss in number does not appear
especially great, but when the ability of the men is taken into consideration the
heavy loss can be appreciated.
The incoming class seems very enthusiastic over all sorts of sports, so we
do not think that there can he much doubt as to the superiority of our teams for

the coming year. But let us impress upon all the necessity of all turning out.
"No," we hear you say, "what's the use of my trying to do anything. I am
worthless, so why should I go to the trouble of 'turning out.'" No, my friend,
you are not "worthless." Come out and show your spirit, and do your best,
something will happen. Some of the best athletes ever produced at this Uni versity were men like you. They had to be coaxed to come out. They thought
themselves "good for nothing," but when they got under the care of a trainer,
they developed, and showed such magnificent qualities that they really surprised
themselves
So, young man, come out, and do your level best for her whom we all love—
our Alma Mater.
PROSPECT FOR FOOT BALL.
UST at present Foot Ball is the engrossing topic. This year Hopkins has
two entirely new features to boast of, viz.: a coach and a training table.
Mr. Dickson, of the U. of P., will handle the men during the season, and
expresses the opinion that a winning team will do the honors for Old Tom
Hopkins on the gridiron. The team will, no doubt, be lighter than last year's,
averaging not over 150 lbs., but this feature will be supplemented by speed and
concerted team work. There's lots of new material this year and some of it
appears to be very good, but we can make no prophecies just yet, as the task
of weeding out the team has not begun. All the candidates are, however, to
be congratulated on their enthusiasm and interest as shown by the large
,numbers which are present for daily practice. There is a rumor afloat that
several Meds, besides those who have already shown up will join these swelling
ranks of Black and Blue Warriors, and there is some splendid material in the
Medical School. The first game is with Rock Hill, at the American League
Park, Saturday, and we prophesy that Rock Hill will count her score with
one oval figure. Season tickets will be sold this year at $1.50 for the entire
schedule of games to be played by J. H. U. in Baltimore, including all the
championship games, also the game with U. of Md. We add in conclusion:
Everybody out next Saturday, the rooting promises to be something fierce; woe
unto the freshman whose chubby face is not to be seen there.

THE GALLERY.
MPROVEMENT is the mark of the age. Last year THE NEWS LETTER
several times called attention to changes being made in and around the
Gymnasium building, and this year, for the first time is it noticed that
accommodations for visitors and onlookers in the cage are both sufficient and
convenient. The gallery was spoken of two years ago and finally built during
the last few weeks of last season. So far the gallery leads in the list of
improvements to our athletic accommodations which began with the building
of the cage some few years ago and have continued ever since. Some day we
will have a swimming pool, Thanks, Mack!

Now that the gallery is ready for occupancy by interested spectators of
team practice, would it be out of place to remind students and others that one
of the main purposes in building it was to save the running track? Formerly
the track was at the mercy of all onlookers in the cage, and it required Mack's
best efforts to keep it in any sort of condition for his men to train. Now we
Should all remember that the cage is for players, the track for runners and the
gallery for spectators.
OUR PHILIPPINE DEPARTMENT.
OHNS Hopkins is the first institution in the country to start a course of
instruction in the dialects, manners and customs of our Eastern possessions. For some time past, the University ha been collecting the available
literature concerning the habits and language of the Filipinos, and now the library contains practically all the books of any value on these subjects to be had
in this country. Dr. Haupt, head of the department of Semitic languages, will
have immediate supervision of the work. The first course offered is an elective
in Tagalog, given by Mr. F. R. Blake, formerly a fellow of the University. Mr.
Blake has specialized in Sanskrit and in the Semitic languages. As the Malay
dialects are mixtures of Sanskrit and Arabic, he is especially well qualified for
the work. Since all the valuable works on this subject are in Spanish or German, Mr. Blake is preparing an English manual of the dialects used on the
islands, designed both for students and for general use.
It is hard to overestimate the importance of this department, and the honor
accruing to the Hopkins for its enterprise in founding it. In Dr. Haupt's words,
concerning the great Sepoy rebellion, "if the English authorities had consulted
anybody familiar with the prejudices of the natives, they would never have
compelled the use of those bullets greased with the fat that was an abomination
to Hindoo and Mohommedan alike. The U. S. Bureau of Ethnology has
already saved to the Government millions of dollars in its dealings with the
Indians." From this is seen the necessity to our country, soon to be a power
in the Orient, of such courses and instructions.
Dr. Haupt has also in view an encyclopedia of the industries, the economical, political, and religious life of the Philippines. For this work, also to be
Published under the auspices of the Hopkins, there has already been enlisted
the assistance of Dr. A. B. Meyer, of Dresden, and Dr. Blumentritt, of Seilmeritz.

LESSON IV.
Whose child is this? It looks around as if it were lost. It really seems to
have lost the lower portion of its pantaloons. Hit it with an Indian club and
see if it will holler. It is calling for the nurse girl. Shove it into long
trousers, place it tenderly in a basket, and send the remains home to dear Papa.

"IN MEMORIAM."
Oh, why will the fortune of life play such pranks?
And why will it out down the young and the brave?
The arch-fiend has busied himself in our ranks,
And carried one off like a dastardly knave.
Had he come, as of yore, with armor and shield,
A warrior tried, seasoned, bearded and gray,
We had fought him and conquered, and forced him to yield
For to win every battle is naughty-two's way.
But he came as an infant all naked and bare,
Deserted, alone, in the mystery of night.
We clothed him and fondled him, gave him our care,
Then why should ho harm us? Oh, say was it right?
Full of treachery and guile with intent to deceive,
He fixed upon one of us innocent youths,
Whispered tales in his ear, that made Law believe,
And made terrible lies, seem like beautiful truths.
Oh, he carried Law off to the false land of dreams,
Deceived by a kiss so subtle and sly,
And now in my sleep I hear pitiful screams;
Our poor comrade tortured, and none of us by.
Oh, Law, fare thee well, thou art gone from us now.
Forever and aye to thy destiny tied,
We will grieve, and in prayer our knee lightly bow;
And mourn for a comrade who lately has died.
—F. L. G-. '02.

NEW UNIVERSITY SONGS.

4T
4j HAS seemed strange to many people outside of the University that the
Hopkins has so few college songs. Some persons have even hinted that
the reason for this was a lack of true college spirit. This explanation,
however, is most decidedly erroneous, for to those who have looked into the
matter at all it is evident that the true reason could more surely be found in
the fact that never before has the attention of the student body been drawn to
the subject of college songs.
"To this end the musical organizations have determined to open a prize
competition for the best words, set either to original or popular music. Of
course, if a song with original words and music is handed in, it will be given

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

preference to verses alone—yet if the words are set to some air which can be
used in the Glee Club or on the athletic grounds, provided neither "Dixie" nor
Georgia" is used, it will stand nearly as good a chance of taking a prize as
the song with original music.
"Three prizes have been offered—the first of $10.00, the second of $5.00,
and the third of $3.00. The Judges will be Dr. Herbert E. Green and Messrs.
E. L. Turnbull, J A. E. Eyster, E. Smith and H. Eager. The prizes will be
decided by the vote of these men.
"It is hoped that every man at present in the University and those formerly
connected with it will take part in this contest, either from a desire to win a
Prize, or from his love for his Alma Mater, or—better yet—from a happy combination of both these incentives."
The above announcement was published in the May issue of the NEWSLETTER, and the competition was to have closed in June. But, after some
consideration, it was decided by those who had charge of the matter to postpone the final decision till the first of November.
By this change more men were given an opportunity to compete; and there
was a greater chance of composing and writing some really good songs.
If a sufficient number of songs are handed in, the committee will have
them published in book form, and thus give to the University the first book of
entirely original Hopkins songs.
Surely, with such a result to crown his efforts, every student who can make
the slightest attempt at poetry should enter the competition, for not only will
he be aiding his college, but he may incidentally win an enviable reputation
and a little cheering' reward.

movement, unhindered by the lower portion of goods common to man! What

LITTLE Boy: Leave me alone. Honestly I won't hurt any of you.
VILLIAN
Come, my darling child; we fear thy strength and prowess.
We fear that thou mighiest harm our Varsity players if thou art allowed to run

thou awakenest, thou wilt find that, like Sampson, thou has been shorn of
